text.*:
Until the 17th century a bard would compose a poem knowing it was going to be sung. Poetry was called music of the tongue and string music was called music of the string. Cerdd means either poetry or music. When bardic music died out the knowledge of how the music was set also died out.[1][2]

References[edit]

  1. ^ Music in Welsh Culture Before 1650: A Study of the Principal Sources by Sally Harper, Routledge, 2007, ISBN 0754652637
  2. ^ Welsh Traditional Music by Phyllis Kinney, University of Wales Press, 2011, ISBN 0708323588
